column8: C1. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
column9: C2. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
column10: C3. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
column11: C4. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
column12: C5. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
column13: C6. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
column14: C7. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
column15: C8. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
column16: C9. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
column17: C10. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
column18: C11. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
column19: C12. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
column20: C13. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
column21: C14. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
column22: C15. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
column23: C16. Genetic research will improve our lives.
column24: C17. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
column25: C18. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
column26: C19. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
column27: C20. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
column28: C21. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
column29: C22. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
column30: C23. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
column31: C24. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
column32: C25. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
column33: C26. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
column34: C27. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
column35: C28. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
column36: C29. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
column37: C30. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
column38: C31. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
column39: C32. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
column40: C33. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
column41: C34. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
column42: C35. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
column43: C36. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
column44: C37. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
column45: C38. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
column46: C39. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
column47: C40. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
column48: C41. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
column49: C42. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
column50: C43. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
column51: C44. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
column52: C45. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
column53: C46. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
column54: C47. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
column55: C48. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
column56: C49. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
